\title{Internal waves, mean\textendash flow and topography interaction:
Channel configuration}
\maketitle

\section{Introduction}

\textbf{Changer 'internal waves' en 'gravity waves'. }One of the major
challenge for improving climate models is to find better parameterizations
of the phenomena occurring at small scales (meaning smaller than the
ocean models typical grid scale) especially in the ocean. The choice
of the resolution for the ocean in climate simulation significantly
impact the simulated large-scale climate and its variability (see
\cite{Kirtman2012}). To tackle the drawing of parameterizations,
it is important to well understand the physics behind. Effects of
importance are the small scale mixing and the dissipation of the tidal
energy. Those effects are strongly correlated in the ocean and a substantial
part seems to be driven by internal wave emission and braking (see
\cite{Ferrari2009}). Close to the ocean floor, the interaction of
the mean flow with submarine topography is expected to generate both
local turbulent mixing near the boundary and lee waves that radiate
energy and eventually brake far away inducing remote mixing. The relative
amounts of remote and local energy dissipation governs the distribution
of mixing within the water column, carrying implications for the evolution
of the abyssal stratification and overturning circulation. Internal
waves are playing an crucial role in an other climate feature, the
quasi\textendash biennial oscillations (see \cite{Plumb1977,Lindzen1968}).
To better understand the physics underlying the internal waves, many
laboratory experiments have been performed. A non\textendash exhaustive
list of references can be found in table \ref{tab:Referencing-of-some}.
The huge difference in scaling between the ocean internal waves and
their laboratory analogues makes the viscous effects significant.
In those experiments, internal waves are often generated by moving
boundaries implying boundary layers effects.

In these notes, we focus on internal waves generated in a 2D\textendash periodic
channel configuration by a undulating bottom boundary either moving
or with a mean\textendash flow passing over it. The inviscid problem
has been extensively studied (see \cite{Muraschko2015}). The presence
of viscous dissipation involves several new feature on the wave field.
First of all, we expect the wave beam to loose its energy by shear
stress such that the wave amplitude decreases exponentially along
the ray. We also expect the existence of a boundary layer to match
the propagative wave with the bottom boundary. In the literature,
the dissipative processes can be parametrized by a spring force on
the buoyancy which tends to bring it back to a stable stratification
profile, linear in most of the case (\textbf{Grisouard and Bühler}).
This parametrization does involve in the amplitude of the propagating
waves but does not involve any boundary layers. The presence of a
dissipative process involves a streaming of a mean-flow. In the present
idealized geometry, this phenomenon is well explained in the framework
of zonally\textendash symmetric waves and mean\textendash flow interaction
(see \cite{Buhler2014}). Compared to the spring like parametrization,
the presence of viscous boundary layers implies a specific streaming
feature close to the bottom boundary which in some cases can be of
importance. ( \textbf{NOTE? :}{[}\textbf{Plumb and McEwan}{]} \textbf{considered
a viscous dissipation process but ignored the associated boundary
layer}. )
\begin{itemize}
\item \textbf{Parler de QBO ?}
\item \textbf{Parler des differentes conditions aux limites.}
\item \textbf{Parler de la viscosité effective dans les simulations de résolution
intermédiaire.}
\end{itemize}
\begin{table}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline 
\textbf{Paper} & $\mathrm{Re}$  & $\mathrm{Fr}$ & $\epsilon$ & $\mathrm{Pr}$ & Generation & Type\tabularnewline
\hline 
\hline 
\cite{Baines1985} & $100-1000$ & $0.1$ & 0.1 & 1000 & ridge drag & Experimental\tabularnewline
\hline 
\cite{Dossmann2016} & $400-87000$ & $0.1-34$ & $0.1-1.$ & 1000 & ridge drag & Experimental\tabularnewline
\hline 
\cite{Peacock2009} & 73 & 0.82 & $0.4$ & 1000 & oscillating cams & Experimental\tabularnewline
\hline 
\cite{Plumb1978} & 1500-3000 & 0.02-0.04 & 0.05 & 1000 & oscillating membranes & Experimental\tabularnewline
\hline 
\cite{Semin2016} & 650 & 0.1 & 0.06 & 1000 & oscillating membranes & Experimental\tabularnewline
\hline 
\end{tabular}

\caption{Referencing of some characteristic dimensionless number in internal
wave experiments.\label{tab:Referencing-of-some} }
\end{table}


\section{The Boussinesq model}

We consider a 2\textendash dimensional linearly stratified fluid in
a channel type periodic domain. The domain is semi-infinite in the
vertical direction. The simplest model we need to consider is the
incompressible Boussinesq model. Two type of dissipative mechanism
will be considered: viscosity and Newtonian cooling. The equation
of state is linear. 

\subsection{Equations}

The flow obeys the Navier-stokes equations in the Boussinesq approximation
: 
\begin{equation}
\begin{cases}
\partial_{t}u+u\partial_{x}u+w\partial_{z}w & =-\partial_{x}P+\nu\Delta u\\
\partial_{t}w+u\partial_{x}w+w\partial_{z}w & =-\partial_{z}P+b+\nu\Delta w\\
\partial_{t}b+u\partial_{x}b+w\partial_{z}b+N^{2}b & =-\alpha b\\
\partial_{x}u+\partial_{z}w & =0
\end{cases},\label{eq:Main_Boussinesq}
\end{equation}
where $\left(x,z\right)$ are the zonal and vertical coordinates,
$\Delta=\partial_{xx}+\partial_{zz}$ is the Laplacian differential
operator , $\left(u,w\right)$ are the components 2\textendash dimensional
velocity vector field, $P$ is the pressure anomaly field, $b$ is
the buoyancy field, $N$ is the Brünt-Väisälä frequency (considered
constant here), $\nu$ is the kinematic viscosity and $\alpha$ is
a relaxation time toward an equilibrium stratification for the buoyancy.
The first equation will be referred to as the zonal momentum equation,
the second one as the vertical momentum equation, the third one as
the buoyancy equation and the last one as the incompressibility condition.
The buoyancy is defined from the mass density $\rho$ through $b=g\frac{\left(\rho_{c}-\rho\right)}{\rho_{c}}-N^{2}z$
where $\rho_{c}$ is a reference value for $\rho$.

\subsubsection*{Boundary conditions}

The domain is periodic in the zonal direction. For any field $\phi\left(x,z\right)$,
we have $\phi\left(x+nL\right)=\phi\left(x\right)$ $\forall\left(x,n\right)\in\mathbb{R}\times\mathbb{Z}$.
$L$ is the zonal period of the domain. At the boundary at the bottom
of the domain will be referred to as topography. Its equation is given
by $z\left(x,t\right)=h_{b}\left(x,t\right)$ with $\int_{0}^{L}h_{b}\left(x,t\right)\mathrm{d}x=0$. 

If $\nu=0$, we consider simply the impermeability condition at the
bottom boundary. It amounts to fixe the normal velocity at the boundary
to be equal to the normal velocity of the topography :
\[
\left(\mathbf{u}\left(x,z=h_{b}\left(x,t\right)\right)-\mathbf{v}_{h_{b}}\left(x,t\right)\right)\cdot\mathbf{n}_{h_{b}}\left(x,t\right)=0\;\forall x,t
\]

If $\nu\neq0$, we can either consider a no\textendash slip or a free\textendash slip
boundary condition :
\begin{itemize}
\item No\textendash slip 
\[
\mathbf{u}\left(x,z=h_{b}\left(x,t\right),t\right)=\mathbf{v}_{h_{b}}\left(x,t\right)\quad\forall x,t
\]
\item Free\textendash slip 
\[
\begin{cases}
\left(\mathbf{u}\left(x,z=h_{b}\left(x,t\right),t\right)-\mathbf{v}_{h_{b}}\left(x,t\right)\right)\cdot\mathbf{n}_{h_{b}}\left(x,t\right) & =0\\
\mathbf{n}_{h_{b}}^{\bot}\left(x,t\right)\cdot\left(\overline{\overline{\sigma}}\left(\mathbf{u}\right)\left(x,z=h_{b}\left(x,t\right)\right)\left[\mathbf{n}_{h_{b}}\left(x,t\right)\right]\right) & =0
\end{cases}\;\forall x,t,
\]
the first equation is the impermeability condition, the second one
is the condition of vanishing tangential constraint. $\overline{\overline{\sigma}}$
is the constraint tensor.
\end{itemize}

\subsection{Energetics and Casimirs}

\subsubsection{Energetics }

Let us introduce the energy density 
\[
e=\frac{u^{2}+w^{2}}{2}+\frac{b^{2}}{2N^{2}}.
\]
We can derive its dynamical equation :
\[
\partial_{t}e+\partial_{x}\left(u\left(e+P\right)\right)+\partial_{z}\left(w\left(e+P\right)\right)=\nu\left(u\Delta u+w\Delta w\right)-\frac{\alpha}{N^{2}}b^{2}
\]
Which leads after integrating over the domain to the energy budget
:
\[
\frac{\mathrm{d}E}{\mathrm{d}t}=-\mathcal{E}_{\nu}-\mathcal{E}_{\alpha}+\mathcal{F}
\]
where 
\begin{eqnarray*}
E & = & \iint\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\:e\\
\mathcal{E}_{\nu} & = & -\iint\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\:\left(u\Delta u+w\Delta w\right)\\
\mathcal{E}_{\alpha} & = & \alpha\iint\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\:b^{2}\\
\mathcal{F} & = & \underset{\partial_{\mathrm{up}}}{\int}\mathrm{d}x\:w\left(e+P\right)
\end{eqnarray*}
where $\partial_{\mathrm{up}}$ is any horizontal line delimiting
the domain above the topography. $E$ is the total energy of the flow,
$\mathcal{E}_{\nu}$ is the viscous energy\textendash dissipation
rate, $\mathcal{E}_{\alpha}$ is the cooling energy\textendash dissipation
rate and $\mathcal{F}$ is the outward energy flux at the upper boundary.

We can separate the energy into a kinetic and a potential part: 
\begin{eqnarray*}
E_{c} & = & \frac{1}{2}\iint\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\:\left(u^{2}+w^{2}\right)\\
E_{p} & = & \frac{1}{2N^{2}}\iint\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}y\:b^{2}
\end{eqnarray*}
Without dissipative effects (i.e. $\nu,\alpha=0$), the total energy
$E$ is conserved by the dynamics.

\subsubsection{Casimirs}

The Casimirs are defined by :

\[
C_{f}=\iint\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{dz}\:f\left(b+N^{2}z\right)
\]
where $f$ is any sufficiently smooth function or distribution. We
have

\[
\frac{dC_{f}}{dt}=-\alpha\iint\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{dz}\:b\,f'\left(b+N^{2}z\right).
\]
Without dissipative effects (i.e. $\nu,\alpha=0$), the Casimirs are
conserved by the dynamics.

\paragraph{\textmd{The }mass distribution \textmd{is given by choosing $f\left(x\right)=\delta\left(x-\sigma_{m}\right)$
:
\[
\mathcal{D}\left(\sigma_{m}\right)=\iint\mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\;\delta\left(b\left(x,z\right)+N^{2}z-\sigma_{m}\right).
\]
The conservation of the mass distribution means that, at any time,
the mass field $b+N^{2}z$ can only be a rearrangement of the initial
field. }}

\subsection{Adimensionalized equations}

Let us consider the parameters of the problem$\left\{ h_{b},N,\omega,k,\nu,\alpha\right\} $
where\textbf{ $h_{b}$, $k$} and $\omega$ are typical values of
the amplitude of the topography, the horizontal wave number and the
angular frequency of the topography. We denote $c=\omega/k$ the associated
phase\textendash speed. We can define three independent dimensionless
parameters :
\[
\begin{cases}
\text{Reynold number :} & \mathrm{Re}=\frac{c}{\nu k}\\
\text{Froude number : } & \mathrm{Fr}=\frac{\omega}{N}\\
\text{Newton number :} & \mathrm{\beta=\frac{\alpha}{\omega}}\\
\text{Topographic aspect ratio :} & \epsilon=h_{b}k
\end{cases}.
\]
The adimensionalized variables writes :
\[
\begin{cases}
\left(\tilde{x},\tilde{z}\right) & =k\left(x,z\right)\\
\tilde{t} & =\omega t\\
\left(\tilde{u},\tilde{w}\right) & =\left(u,w\right)/c\\
\tilde{b} & =kb/N^{2}\\
\tilde{P} & =P/c^{2}
\end{cases}
\]
This leads to, if we drop the tilde :
\begin{equation}
\begin{cases}
\partial_{t}u+u\partial_{x}u+w\partial_{z}u & =-\partial_{x}P+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Re}}\Delta u\\
\partial_{t}w+u\partial_{x}w+w\partial_{z}w & =-\partial_{z}P+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}b+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Re}}\Delta w\\
\partial_{t}b+u\partial_{x}b+w\partial_{z}b+w & =-\beta b\\
\partial_{x}u+\partial_{z}w & =0
\end{cases}\label{eq:GlobalEQ_NonLin}
\end{equation}
Let us write down the bottom boundary conditions :
\begin{itemize}
\item Impermeability
\[
w-v_{z,hb}=\epsilon\left(u-u_{x,h_{B}}\right)\partial_{x}h_{b}|_{z=\epsilon h_{b}}
\]
\item Viscous boundary conditions :
\end{itemize}

\paragraph*{Free-slip : \textmd{No tangential constraint }
\[
\left(\partial_{z}u+\partial_{x}w\right)\frac{\left(1-\left(\epsilon\partial_{x}h_{b}\right)^{2}\right)}{2}-\epsilon\partial_{x}h_{b}\left(\partial_{x}u-\partial_{z}w\right)=0|_{z=\epsilon h_{b}}
\]
}

\paragraph{No-slip : \textmd{Cancelation of the velocity}
\[
\mathbf{u}|_{z=\epsilon h_{b}}=\mathbf{v}_{h_{b}}
\]
}

\section{Zonally symmetric wave\textendash mean flow interaction}

Let us introduce the zonal average operator by 
\[
\overline{\phi}\left(z,t\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{0}^{2\pi}\mathrm{d}x\;\phi\left(x,z,t\right),
\]
where $\phi$ is any field. We define the waves-mean flow decomposition
by 
\[
\left(u,w,b,P\right)=\left(\overline{u},\overline{w},\overline{b},\overline{P}\right)+\left(u',w',b',P'\right),
\]
 the fields $\left(\overline{u},\overline{w},\overline{b},\overline{P}\right)$
will be referred to as the mean\textendash flow and the fields $\left(u',w',b',P'\right)$
as the waves. 

We can notice that if there is no Newtonian cooling (i.e. $\beta=0$),
then the mass distribution is conserved and, thus, the mass field
as to be a rearrangement of the initial mass field. If we assume this
initial field to by linear then $\overline{b}+b'=N^{2}\zeta\left(x,z,t\right)$
where $\zeta$ is a vertical displacement field. From incompressibility,
we have $\overline{\zeta}=0$. This means that the mean buoyancy is
zero at any time. For a non linear initial stratification\textbf{
$S_{bg}\left(z\right)$, $\overline{b}$ }will be given by a series
$\sum_{k=2}^{\infty}S_{bg}^{\left(k\right)}\left(z\right)\overline{\zeta^{k}}/k!$
which is bounded by the amplitude of the fluctuations. 

The coupled waves-mean flow equations are given by simply applying
the zonal average to\textbf{ (\ref{eq:GlobalEQ_NonLin}) }and using
the zonal periodicity :
\[
\begin{cases}
\partial_{t}\overline{u}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Re}}\partial_{zz}\overline{u} & =-\partial_{z}\overline{w'u'}\\
\overline{P} & =\overline{w'^{2}}\\
\overline{w} & =0\\
\partial_{t}\overline{b} & =-\partial_{z}\overline{b'w'}-\beta\overline{b}
\end{cases}
\]
The second equation is simply a diagnostic equation giving the mean
pressure field. Also the fourth equation has to be satisfied by the
diagnostic expression of $\overline{b}$ given above. This means that
$\partial_{z}\overline{b'w'}$ has to be a time partial\textendash derivative
of a bounded quantity. We focus ourselves on the mean\textendash momentum
equation carrying all the interesting physics :
\[
\boxed{\partial_{t}\overline{u}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Re}}\partial_{zz}\overline{u}=-\partial_{z}\overline{u'w'}}.
\]
The important term is the Reynold stress $\partial_{z}\overline{u'w'}$
in the zonal mean flow equation. It is computed from the fluctuations,
i.e. the waves in the limit of small amplitude. Subtracting the mean\textendash flow
equations to \textbf{(\ref{eq:GlobalEQ_NonLin})}, we obtain the equations
for the fluctuations
\[
\begin{cases}
\partial_{t}u'+\overline{u}\partial_{x}u'+w'\partial_{z}\overline{u}+\mathcal{B}\left(\mathbf{u}',u'\right) & =-\partial_{x}P'+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Re}}\Delta u'\\
\partial_{t}w'+\overline{u}\partial_{x}w'+\mathcal{B}\left(\mathbf{u}',w'\right) & =-\partial_{z}P'+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}b'+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Re}}\Delta w'\\
\partial_{x}u'+\partial_{z}w' & =0\\
\partial_{t}b'+\overline{u}\partial_{x}b''+w'+\mathcal{B}\left(\mathbf{u}',b'\right) & =-\beta b'
\end{cases}
\]
where $\mathcal{B}\left(\mathbf{u}',\phi'\right)=u'\partial_{x}\phi'+w'\partial_{z}\phi'-\overline{u'\partial_{x}\phi'+w'\partial_{z}\phi}$
is a bilinear operator with zero zonal average.

In principle, we perform the same flow decomposition at the boundaries
in order to get the boundary condition for wave and mean part but
this formulation make sense only in a far-field approximation when
the domain geometry is asymptotically flat. If one want to consider
a proper definition of the mean flow close to the topography, one
would have to consider the Lagrangian-mean theory.

\paragraph{Energy budget}

Let us recall the energy density equation : 
\[
\partial_{t}e+\partial_{x}\left(u\left(e+P\right)\right)+\partial_{z}\left(w\left(e+P\right)\right)=\frac{1}{\mathrm{Re}}\left(u\Delta u+w\Delta w\right)-\frac{\beta}{\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}b^{2}
\]
where 
\[
e=\frac{u^{2}+w^{2}}{2}+\frac{b^{2}}{2\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}.
\]
The mean upward energy\textendash flux writes 
\[
\overline{J_{z}}=\overline{w\left(e+P\right)}=\overline{w'P'}+\overline{u}\overline{u'w'}+\frac{1}{\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}\overline{b}\overline{w'b'}+\overline{w'e_{w}}
\]
with $e_{w}=\frac{u'^{2}+w'^{2}}{2}+\frac{b'^{2}}{2\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}$.
The zonal average of the energy density equation writes :
\[
\partial_{t}\overline{e}+\partial_{z}\left(\overline{J_{z}}-\frac{\overline{u'^{2}}+\overline{w'^{2}}+\overline{u}^{2}}{2\mathrm{Re}}\right)=-\frac{1}{\mathrm{Re}}\left(\left(\partial_{z}\overline{u}\right)^{2}+\overline{\left(\partial_{x}u'\right)^{2}}+\overline{\left(\partial_{z}u'\right)^{2}}+\overline{\left(\partial_{x}w'\right)^{2}}+\overline{\left(\partial_{z}w'\right)^{2}}\right).
\]
The mean energy is decomposed into a mean-flow component and a wave
component : 
\[
\overline{e}=e_{\mathrm{mf}}+\overline{e_{w}}
\]
with 
\[
e_{\mathrm{mf}}=\frac{\overline{u}^{2}}{2}+\frac{\overline{b}^{2}}{2\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}
\]


\section{Internal waves within a weakly sheared mean-flow}

We consider here a single topographic mode $k=\pm1$ and a single
phase speed $c=\pm1$. We consider the limit a small topographic aspect
ratio (i.e. $\epsilon\ll1$). In this limit we can consider an asymptotically
square domain with a bottom boundary condition expressed at $z=0$
in terms of a series of power of $\epsilon$:
\begin{itemize}
\item Impermeability
\[
\sum_{n=2}^{\infty}\epsilon^{n}h_{b}^{n-1}\left(h_{b}\partial_{z}^{n}w-\partial_{x}h_{b}\partial_{z}^{n-1}u\right)+w-v_{z,h_{b}}+\epsilon\left(h_{b}\partial_{z}w-\left(u-u_{x,h_{B}}\right)\partial_{x}h_{b}|_{z=\epsilon h_{b}}\right)=0.
\]
\item Viscous boundary conditions :
\end{itemize}

\paragraph*{Free-slip : \textmd{No tangential constraint }
\[
\sum_{n=2}^{\infty}\epsilon^{n}\left(\frac{h_{b}^{n}}{2}\left(\partial_{z}^{n+1}u+\partial_{x}\partial_{z}^{n}w\right)-\frac{\partial_{x}\left(h_{b}^{n-1}\right)\partial_{x}h_{b}}{2\left(n-1\right)}\left(\partial_{z}^{n-1}u+\partial_{x}\partial_{z}^{n-2}w\right)-\frac{\partial_{x}\left(h_{b}^{n}\right)}{n}\left(\partial_{x}\partial_{z}^{n-1}u-\partial_{z}^{n+1}w\right)\right)+\epsilon\left(\frac{h_{b}}{2}\left(\partial_{zz}u+\partial_{zx}w\right)-\partial_{x}h_{b}\left(\partial_{x}u-\partial_{z}w\right)\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\partial_{z}u+\partial_{x}w\right)=0.
\]
}

\paragraph{No-slip : \textmd{Cancelation of the velocity}
\[
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\epsilon^{n}h_{b}^{n}\partial_{z}^{n}\mathbf{u}=\mathbf{v}_{h_{b}}.
\]
}

Let us introduce a small parameter $\epsilon^{2}\ll a\ll1$. We will
see later how it scales with $\epsilon$. Let us introduce a slow
variable $Z=az$. We now assume that the mean flow $\overline{u}$
depend only on $Z$. This mean that for the wave field, the mean flow
appears weakly sheared and frozen in time.

Let us introduce the following WKB expansion of a stationary solution
of the wave-equation
\[
\left[\begin{array}{c}
u'\\
w'\\
b'\\
p'
\end{array}\right]=\epsilon\sum_{j=0}^{+\infty}a^{j}\mathbb{R}\mathrm{e}\left\{ \left[\begin{array}{c}
\tilde{u}{}_{j}\left(Z\right)\\
\tilde{w}{}_{j}\left(Z\right)\\
\tilde{b}{}_{j}\left(Z\right)\\
\tilde{p}_{j}\left(Z\right)
\end{array}\right]\exp\left(ik\left(ct-x\right)-\frac{i\Phi\left(Z\right)}{a}\right)\right\} .
\]
Injecting this expansion into the previous equation and collecting
the leading order in $a$ leads :
\[
\epsilon\boldsymbol{\mathrm{M}}\left[\begin{array}{c}
\tilde{u}{}_{0}\\
\tilde{w}{}_{0}\\
\tilde{b}{}_{0}\\
\tilde{p}{}_{0}
\end{array}\right]+\epsilon a\left(\boldsymbol{\mathrm{M}}\left[\begin{array}{c}
\tilde{u}{}_{1}\\
\tilde{w}{}_{1}\\
\tilde{b}{}_{1}\\
\tilde{p}{}_{1}
\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{c}
\tilde{w}{}_{0}\partial_{Z}\overline{u}+\frac{i}{\mathrm{Re}}\left(\tilde{u}_{0}\partial_{Z}m+2m\partial_{Z}\tilde{u}_{0}\right)\\
\partial_{Z}\tilde{P}{}_{0}+\frac{i}{\mathrm{Re}}\left(\tilde{w}_{0}\partial_{Z}m+2m\partial_{Z}\tilde{w}_{0}\right)\\
0\\
\partial_{Z}\tilde{w}{}_{0}
\end{array}\right]\right)+o\left(\epsilon a\right)=0
\]
with 
\[
\boldsymbol{\mathrm{M}}=\left[\begin{array}{cccc}
ik\left(c-\overline{u}\right)\left(1-i\frac{k^{2}+m^{2}}{\mathrm{Re}k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right) & 0 & 0 & -ik\\
0 & ik\left(c-\overline{u}\right)\left(1-i\frac{k^{2}+m^{2}}{\mathrm{Re}k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right) & -\frac{1}{\mathrm{Fr}^{2}} & -im\\
0 & 1 & ik\left(c-\overline{u}\right)\left(1-i\frac{\beta}{k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right) & 0\\
-ik & -im & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right]\qquad\text{ and }m=\partial_{Z}\phi
\]
This implies 
\[
\det\boldsymbol{\mathrm{M}}=0\implies\mathrm{Fr}^{2}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\left(1-i\frac{\left(k^{2}+m^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Re}k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right)\left(1-i\frac{\beta}{k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right)\left(k^{2}+m^{2}\right)=1\qquad\text{ and }\qquad\left[\begin{array}{c}
\tilde{u}{}_{0}\\
\tilde{w}{}_{0}\\
\tilde{b}{}_{0}\\
\tilde{p}{}_{0}
\end{array}\right]=\phi_{0}\left(Z\right)\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}\left(Z\right)
\]
where $\tilde{\phi}_{0}$ measures the global amplitude of the wave
and $\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}$ is the polarization of the wave given
by 
\[
\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
c-\overline{u}\\
-{\displaystyle \frac{k}{m}}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)\\
{\displaystyle -\frac{i}{m\left(1-i\frac{\beta}{k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right)}}\\
\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\left(1-i\frac{\left(k^{2}+m^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Re}k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right)
\end{array}\right].
\]
We now project the order one terms on
\[
\left[\begin{array}{c}
c-\overline{u}\\
-{\displaystyle \frac{k}{m}}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)\\
{\displaystyle \frac{i}{\mathrm{Fr}^{2}m\left(1-i\frac{\beta}{k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right)}}\\
\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\left(1-i\frac{\left(k^{2}+m^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Re}k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right)
\end{array}\right].
\]
This leads toward a messy equation for the wave\textendash amplitude
$\phi_{0}\left(Z\right)$ :
\[
\frac{1}{\phi_{0}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\partial_{Z}\left(\phi_{0}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)\right)=\frac{2\left(k^{2}-m^{2}\right)+ik\mathrm{Re}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}{4m^{2}\left(2\left(k^{2}+m^{2}\right)+ik\mathrm{Re}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)\right)}\partial_{Z}m^{2}
\]


\subsection{Case $\mathrm{Re=\infty}$ and $\beta>0$:}

We have 
\[
\mathrm{Fr}^{2}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\left(1-i\frac{\beta}{k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right)\left(k^{2}+m^{2}\right)=1.
\]
This is an 2nd-order equation. There is only one propagative branch
for $m$ . In the limit of $\beta\ll1$, we have :
\[
m=\pm\left(\underbrace{\sqrt{\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}-k^{2}}}_{m_{0}}+i\frac{\beta}{2\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{3}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}\sqrt{\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}}-k^{2}}}\right).
\]
In the limit $\beta\ll1$, we also have :

\paragraph{
\[
\partial_{Z}\left(\frac{\phi_{0}^{2}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}-k^{2}}}\right)=0.
\]
\textmd{The vertical group velocity is defined by : 
\[
\mathbf{u}_{g}\equiv\frac{k}{\partial_{c}\mathbb{Re}\left[m\right]}\protect\underset{\beta\to0}{\sim}\mp\frac{km_{0}}{k^{2}+m_{0}^{2}}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)
\]
}}

\subsection{Case $\beta=0$ and $\mathrm{Re}<\infty$ :}

We have 
\[
\mathrm{Fr}^{2}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\left(1-i\frac{\left(k^{2}+m^{2}\right)}{\mathrm{Re}k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)}\right)\left(k^{2}+m^{2}\right)=1.
\]
This an 4th\textendash order equation. There is two branches for $m$.
A propagative one and a boundary layer one. In the limit of $\mathrm{Re}\gg1$,
we have :
\begin{itemize}
\item if $k^{2}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}<1$:
\begin{align*}
m_{\mathrm{Prop}} & =\pm\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr^{2}}}-k^{2}}+\frac{i}{2k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{3}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}\mathrm{Re}\sqrt{\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}-k^{2}}}\right)+o\left(\mathrm{Re}^{-1}\right)\\
m_{\mathrm{bl}} & =\pm\left(1-\mathrm{sign}\left(k\right)i\right)\sqrt{\frac{\left|c-\overline{u}\right|\left|k\right|\mathrm{Re}}{2}}+o\left(\sqrt{\mathrm{Re}}\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
m_{\mathrm{Prop}}^{2} & =\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}-k^{2}+\frac{i}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{5}\mathrm{Fr}^{4}k\mathrm{Re}}+o\left(\mathrm{Re}^{-1}\right)\\
m_{\mathrm{bl}}^{2} & =-i\left(c-\overline{u}\right)k\mathrm{Re}+o\left(\mathrm{Re}\right)
\end{align*}
Then for $m_{\mathrm{Prop}}$, we have at leading order in $\mathrm{Re}$:
\[
\partial_{Z}\left(\frac{\phi_{0,\mathrm{Prop}}^{2}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}-k^{2}}}\right)=0
\]
and for $m_{\mathrm{bl}}$, we have at leading order in $\mathrm{Re}$:
\[
\partial_{Z}\left(\phi_{0,\mathrm{bl}}m_{\mathrm{bl}}\right)=0
\]
\item if $k^{2}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}>1$:
\begin{align*}
m_{\mathrm{Prop}} & =\pm\left(i\sqrt{k^{2}-\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr^{2}}}}+\frac{1}{2k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{3}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}\mathrm{Re}\sqrt{k^{2}-\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr^{2}}}}}\right)+o\left(\mathrm{Re}^{-1}\right)\\
m_{\mathrm{bl}} & =\pm\left(1-\mathrm{sign}\left(k\left(c-\overline{u}\right)\right)i\right)\sqrt{\frac{\left|c-\overline{u}\right|\left|k\right|\mathrm{Re}}{2}}+o\left(\sqrt{\mathrm{Re}}\right)
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
m_{\mathrm{Prop}}^{2} & =\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}-k^{2}+\frac{i}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{5}\mathrm{Fr}^{4}k\mathrm{Re}}+o\left(\mathrm{Re}^{-1}\right)\\
m_{\mathrm{bl}}^{2} & =-i\left(c-\overline{u}\right)k\mathrm{Re}+o\left(\mathrm{Re}\right)
\end{align*}
Then for $m_{\mathrm{Prop}}$, we have at leading order in $\mathrm{Re}$:
\[
\partial_{Z}\left(\frac{\phi_{0,\mathrm{Prop}}^{2}\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}}{\sqrt{k^{2}-\frac{1}{\left(c-\overline{u}\right)^{2}\mathrm{Fr}^{2}}}}\right)=0
\]
and for $m_{\mathrm{bl}}$, we have at leading order in $\mathrm{Re}$:
\[
\partial_{Z}\left(\phi_{0,\mathrm{bl}}m_{\mathrm{bl}}\right)=0
\]
\end{itemize}
\bibliographystyle{plain}
\bibliography{Biblio/Bibliographie}

\end{document}
